questions.question: A 25-year-old female presents with hypopigmented patches on her skin and silvery-white hair. She also experiences easy bruising and prolonged bleeding following minor injuries. Examination reveals reduced iris pigmentation and visual impairment. Which primary pathological mechanism contributes to the hypopigmented skin observed in this patient?

options.A: Ceroid lipofuscin accumulation in epidermal cells
options.C: Defective melanosome formation, trafficking, or transfer to keratinocytes
options.D: Autophagocytosis and defective fission of large melanosomes

questions.explanation: symptoms of bleeding diathesis (easy bruising, prolonged bleeding following minor injuries), hypopigmentation of skin, hair & eyes with visual impairment & reduced iris pigmentation (oculocutaneous albinism), is suggestive of Hermansky-Pudlak syndrome. Hermansky–Pudlak syndrome (HPS) is a rare, autosomal recessive form of oculocutaneous albinism and non-pigmented symptoms such as bleeding diathesis . It is caused by mutations in genes encoding components of specific protein complexes involved in lysosome biogenesis and trafficking. These mutations lead to impaired melanosome maturation and the absence of dense bodies in platelets. Common manifestations across HPS subtypes include reduced pigmentation in the eyes, hair, and skin, along with easy bruising, bleeding tendencies, interstitial pulmonary fibrosis , and granulomatous colitis in severe cases. Platelet granule defects: Alpha granule defect- Grey platelet syndrome Delta granule defect- Hermansky Pudlak syndrome OTHER OPTIONS: Option A: Ceroid lipofuscin accumulation is observed in abnormal lysosomes of various organs in HPS, including alveolar macrophages in the lungs, it is not primarily associated with epidermal cells in the skin. Option B: Weibel-Palade bodies are secretory granules found in endothelial cells and are involved in regulating vascular function. Dysregulation of Weibel-Palade bodies can result in impaired hemostasis, endothelial dysfunction, and a high risk of thrombus formation. Option D: Autophagocytosis and defective fission of large melanosomes are seen in Chediak-Higashi syndrome, which occurs due to a loss-of-function mutation in the LYST gene (lysosomal trafficking regulator/CHS 1).

questions.question: A 30-year-old woman presents with hypopigmented patches on her chest and back after recovering from a severe rash caused by contact dermatitis. The affected areas are smooth, without any scaling, itching, or scarring. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Post-inflammatory hypopigmentation Explanation: Post-inflammatory hypopigmentation can occur after any skin condition, particularly in darker skin, and is caused by decreased melanin production or transfer to keratinocytes. Post-inflammatory hypopigmentation (PIH): Post-inflammatory hypopigmentation refers to the loss of normal skin color, appearing as lighter patches after skin inflammation subsides. It is the most frequent cause of acquired hypopigmentation. Common side effect of topical corticosteroid use. Darker skin types are more prone to developing PIH. Factors : Impaired Melanin Transfer: Inflammation can disrupt the normal process of melanin transfer from melanocytes (pigment-producing cells) to keratinocytes (skin cells). Melanocyte Loss: The inflammatory process can damage or destroy melanocytes, leading to reduced melanin production. Topical Corticosteroids: While effective in reducing inflammation, potent topical corticosteroids can also inhibit melanin production. PIH is often reversible, especially if melanin production and transfer can be restored. Treatment : Avoiding triggers. Protecting the skin from sun exposure , as UV radiation can worsen hypopigmentation. Vitiligo (Option B) is also characterized by hypopigmented macules, it is less likely in this case because it is related to a previous inflammatory condition. Pityriasis alba (Option C) typically presents as hypopigmented, slightly scaly patches on the face or upper body, often in children or young adults with a history of atopic dermatitis. It is usually characterized by mild scaling or dryness, which was not mentioned in the question. Nevus depigmentosus (Option D) is a congenital, stable, hypopigmented macule that is usually present at birth and does not change in size or shape. Reference: https://www.uptodate.com/contents/acquired-hypopigmentation-disorders-other-than-vitiligo?search=po st%20inflammatory%20hypopigmentation&source=search_result&selectedTitle=1%7E17&usage_type=default&di splay_rank=1

questions.question: A 32 y/o male presents to the clinic with progressively enlarging, hypopigmented patches on the backs of both hands. He has worked in a chemical factory for the past five years, handling various industrial solvents. Wood’s lamp examination reveals well-demarcated depigmented patches with no fluorescence. What chemical is the most likely cause of the patient's condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) p-Tertiary-butylphenol Explanation: The scenario describes a typical presentation of chemical leukoderma in the context of occupational exposure to a substituted phenol. p-Tertiary-butylphenol substituted phenol is a known cause of the chemical leukoderma. Chemical Clinical Presentation Monobenzylether of hydroquinone Confetti-like areas of depigmentation, typically where it is applied. 4-Tertiary-butyl-catechol Depigmentation, particularly on the hands; areas may enlarge, and new ones may appear even after contact has ceased. Phenolic germicides Depigmentation Para tertiary butyl phenol Bindi dermatitis MBEH (mercaptobenzothiazole) Rubber chappals dermatitis Option A: Kojic acid is a skin-lightening agent used in some cosmetic products, it is not typically associated with chemical leukoderma. Option B: Azelaic acid is another compound used in treating hyperpigmentation, it is not a common cause of chemical leukoderma. Option D: While mercury can cause skin discoloration, it typically presents as a blue-grey or purplish pigmentation on light-exposed skin and the sclerae. Reference: https://www.uptodate.com/contents/acquired-hypopigmentation-disorders-other-than-vitiligo?search=ch emical%20leukoderma&sectionRank=1&usage_type=default&anchor=H719407036&source=machineLearning&s electedTitle=1%7E5&display_rank=1#H719407036

questions.question: A 32 y/o female presents with gradually progressive, well-demarcated hypopigmented patches on her face. She has a history of melasma for which she has been using a triple-combination cream containing hydroquinone, tretinoin, and a corticosteroid for the past year. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Drug induced Leukoderma Explanation: Given the patient's history of using a hydroquinone-containing cream and the clinical presentation of hypopigmented patches the most likely diagnosis is drug induced Leukoderma. Topical or Intralesional Corticosteroids Gefitinib (EGFR inhibitor) Imatinib Mesylate (Tyrosine kinase inhibitor) Pegylated Interferon (Immunomodulator) Topical Imiquimod (Immunomodulator) Transdermal Methylphenidate (CNS stimulant) Localized hypopigmentation/depigmentation can be seen at the site of application. Chemical leukoderma : Develops due to exposure to certain drugs containing chemicals that have a toxic effect on melanocytes, resulting in the loss of pigment in the affected skin areas. Causes : p-Tertiary-butylphenol and the monobenzylether of hydroquinone. Mechanism : Selective, lethal effect on functional melanocytes Clinical Presentation : Appearance : Well-defined areas of depigmentation on the skin. The hands, particularly the dorsal, are the most common sites due to frequent contact. Progression : Depigmented areas may expand, and new lesions can appear even after ceasing contact with the causative agent. Treatment : Avoid contact with the identified chemical. Repigmentation may occur naturally over time. Option A: While vitiligo presents with depigmented patches, it is characterized by a complete absence of melanocytes and typically presents with milky-white macules. Option C: Post-inflammatory hypopigmentation: This type of hypopigmentation occurs following skin inflammation, but it is not typically associated with the use of triple-combination creams for melasma. Option D: Melasma is characterized by hyperpigmentation, not hypopigmentation.

questions.question: A 30-year-old woman was diagnosed with vitiligo with lesions as shown below. They have been stable for the past few years, with no other lesions elsewhere. What is the most likely clinical subtype of vitiligo in this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Acrofacial vitiligo Explanation: The image and clinical description suggest vitiligo lesions localised to the face , particularly around the perioral and periorbital areas, which is characteristic of acrofacial vitiligo . Vitiligo can be classified as segmental and non-segmental types. Segmental vitiligo involves depigmentation along a specific segment/dermatome with one or more white macules on one side of the body, usually not crossing the midline. It often begins during childhood or early adulthood and usually stabilizes within a year, with limited spread beyond the affected dermatome. Non-segmental vitiligo includes: Acrofacial -Affects face, head, hands, and feet, and preferably involves the perioral region and the extremities of digits Mucosal - Affects the oral and genital mucosae. (Option B ruled out) Generalized or Common - Often symmetrical, can affect any part of the tegument, mainly hands, fingers, face, and trauma-exposed areas. (Option D ruled out) Universal - Affects 80-90% of the body surface, the most common form in adulthood. (Option C ruled out) Mixed - Simultaneous involvement of segmental and non-segmental vitiligo Poor prognostic factors of vitiligo: Long-standing disease. Lesions on resistant areas like Bony prominences, non-hairy areas, mucosae, ankle wrist, elbow, lips, and genitalia. Associated with Leukotrichia.

questions.question: A 7-year-old child presents with characteristic findings of Waardenburg syndrome, including wide-set eyes (hypertelorism), a broad nasal bridge, and a white forelock of hair. The child's father is also affected. What is the most likely inheritance pattern of Waardenburg syndrome in this case, and how would you counsel the parents regarding the risk of recurrence in future pregnancies?

options.A: Autosomal dominant inheritance; 50% risk of recurrence in each pregnancy
options.B: Autosomal recessive inheritance; 25% risk of recurrence in each pregnancy
options.C: X-linked recessive inheritance; 25% risk of recurrence in each pregnancy
options.D: Sporadic occurrence; negligible risk of recurrence in future pregnancies

questions.explanation: recurrence in each pregnancy. Waardenburg syndrome (WS) is a group of genetic conditions inherited in an autosomal dominant fashion. Autosomal dominant inheritance means that a child only needs to inherit one copy of the mutated gene from either parent to express the trait. This means that if one parent carries the mutated gene, there's a 50% chance of passing it on to each child. Hence, in each pregnancy where one parent carries the gene, there's a 50% risk of the child having Waardenburg syndrome. Reference: Rooks textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition page no 70.4

questions.question: A 25-year-old female presents to the clinic with complaints of easy bruising, recurrent nosebleeds, and progressive shortness of breath over the past few years. Physical examination reveals hypopigmentation of the skin, hair, and eyes. Upon further inquiry, the patient mentions a family history of similar symptoms in her siblings. Which of the following diagnostic tests is most likely to confirm the suspected diagnosis in this patient?
questions.explanation: symptoms of bleeding diathesis (easy bruising, recurrent nosebleeds), hypopigmentation of skin, hair & eyes (oculocutaneous albinism), shortness of breath, and family history of similar symptoms is suggestive of Hermansky-Pudlak syndrome. Diagnostic evaluation involves electron microscopy of platelets to detect absent dense bodies, which serves as a standard diagnostic test. Upon platelet stimulation, dense bodies containing ADP, ATP, serotonin, calcium, and phosphate release their contents to attract other platelets. OTHER OPTIONS: Option A: A platelet aggregation assay is not typically used to diagnose Hermansky–Pudlak syndrome (HPS). While bleeding tendencies are characteristic, the primary diagnostic test for HPS involves assessing platelet morphology rather than function. Option B: Pulmonary function tests may aid in the diagnosis and monitoring of complications such as interstitial pulmonary fibrosis in Hermansky–Pudlak syndrome. Option D: Genetic sequencing of HPS-associated genes can confirm the diagnosis by identifying mutations in genes associated with HPS. However, compared to the direct observation of platelet morphology, it is not always readily available or necessary for initial diagnosis.

questions.question: A 30-year-old patient complains of increased skin pigmentation following prolonged sun exposure. Which of the following statements regarding melanin physiology is most accurate? UV radiation.

options.A: Melanocytes primarily produce eumelanin, responsible for skin pigmentation and protection against
options.B: Tyrosinase is an enzyme that converts tyrosine to melanin in keratinocytes.
options.C: Melanosome transfer from melanocytes to keratinocytes occurs via exocytosis.
options.D: Individuals with albinism have increased melanin production due to mutations in the MC1R gene.

questions.explanation: and protection against UV radiation. melanin, a pigment responsible for skin colouration, hair, and eyes. Eumelanin, along with pheomelanin, is one of the two main types of melanin produced by melanocytes. It ranges from brown to black and protects against harmful ultraviolet (UV) radiation by absorbing and scattering UV light, thereby reducing the risk of DNA damage and skin cancer. OTHER OPTIONS: Option B: Tyrosinase is a crucial enzyme in melanin synthesis, but it functions primarily within melanocytes, not keratinocytes. Tyrosinase catalyzes the conversion of the amino acid tyrosine to dopaquinone, a melanin precursor, within melanocytes' specialized melanosome organelles. Option C: Melanosome transfer from melanocytes to keratinocytes typically occurs through dendricity or melanosome transfer, not exocytosis. Epidermal melanin unit=1:36 In dendritic, melanocytes extend their dendrites to transfer melanosomes directly to neighbouring keratinocytes, enhancing skin pigmentation and UV protection in the epidermis. Option D: Albinism is characterized by reduced or absent melanin production, leading to lighter skin, hair, and eye colouration. It is caused by genetic mutations affecting enzymes involved in melanin synthesis, such as tyrosinase or other proteins in the melanin pathway, not mutations in the MC1R gene, which is associated with the regulation of melanin synthesis and pigmentation. Reference: Fitzpatrick's Dermatology in General Medicine, 9th Edition, Chapter 75, Page 1205.

questions.question: A 5-year-old child is brought to the dermatologist by concerned parents due to their child's extremely fair skin, white hair, and pale blue eyes. Upon examination, the dermatologist confirms the absence of melanin pigment in the child's skin, hair, and irises. The child also shows signs of photophobia and is noted to have nystagmus. Which of the following inheritance patterns is associated with this condition?
questions.explanation: of the skin and hair, ocular manifestations such as nystagmus and photophobia suggest oculocutaneous albinism. It is associated with an autosomal recessive pattern. Oculocutaneous albinism (OCA) is a rare genetic disorder characterized by generalized hypopigmentation and ophthalmological anomalies caused by a deficiency in melanin biosynthesis with normal melanocyte count. There are seven types of OCA, all of which are associated with an autosomal recessive inheritance pattern. There can be either failure of synthesis of tyrosinase enzyme or defect in tyrosinase activity. Clinical features include hypopigmentation of skin, hair, and eyes and ocular findings such as photophobia (which may be prominent). Iris translucency can be demonstrated by slit-lamp examination. A characteristic finding is the misrouting of the optic nerves, consisting of an excessive crossing of the fibres in the optic chiasma, which can result in strabismus and reduced stereoscopic vision. Note: Ocular albinism has an X-linked recessive inheritance pattern.

Nevus anemicus (Option C) typically presents as hypopigmented macules due to persistent cutaneous vasoconstriction resulting from hypersensitivity to catecholamines that become more pronounced with rubbing or trauma. It does not follow the lines of Blaschko. Piebaldism (Option D) is an autosomal dominant condition that presents with depigmented patches on the skin and a characteristic white

questions.question: A 28-year-old female on OCP presents with hyperpigmented macules on her cheeks and forehead. On examination, the lesions appear darker than the surrounding skin and have scalloped margins. There is no associated inflammation or itching. What is the most likely diagnosis based on the clinical presentation?
questions.explanation: her cheek and a history of OCP use most likely has melasma. Melasma is characterized by hyperpigmented macules with scalloped or irregular margins that are darker than the surrounding areas. These patches typically appear on the face, with common locations being the cheeks, forehead, and chin. Etiologic factors include genetic influences, ultraviolet (UV) radiation, pregnancy, hormonal therapies (Ex-OCPs), cosmetics, and phototoxic drugs. Sun protection with broad-spectrum sunscreen with a high SPF, wearing protective clothing, and avoiding prolonged sun exposure aim to prevent further pigmentation. Topical hydroquinone inhibits tyrosinase, an enzyme responsible for pigment production in melanocytes, and is a common depigmenting agent. Triple combination therapy of hydroquinone, retinoid, and corticosteroid is highly effective for melasma. Chemical peels, azelaic acid, and laser therapy are other options. questions.question: A 5-month-old infant presents with a large, darkly pigmented lesion on their lower back. The lesion has been present since birth and has increased proportionally in size with the infant's growth. There is also the presence of hypertrichosis (excessive hair growth) within the lesion. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Congenital Melanocytic Nevus Explanation: In the above scenario, nevi are present at birth and are associated with hypertrichosis and rugosities. Congenital Melanocytic Nevus is the most likely diagnosis. Congenital Melanocytic Nevi (CMN): These are benign growths of melanocytes (pigment-producing cells), present at birth. CMN arise from the neural crest, a temporary group of cells in embryonic development. Characteristics : A single lesion. Exhibit hypertrichosis (increased hair growth) and rugosities (a wrinkled appearance). Classification : Congenital : Present at birth. Acquired : Develop after birth. Size and Malignant Potential : Small to Medium CMN: Benign. Large/Giant CMN (Bathing Trunk/Garment Nevi): Higher risk of developing melanoma (skin cancer). Treatment : Surgical removal, laser therapy, or other therapies. Mongolian spots (Option B) are typically bluish macules found in the sacral area. They tend to fade over time and are not associated with hypertrichosis. Nevus of Ota (Option C) a bluish/slate-gray patch affecting ophthalmic (V1) and maxillary (V2) branches of the trigeminal nerve, face, eyes, oral mucosa. Nevus Depigmentosus (Option D) presents as a single hypopigmented (lighter) macule, typically present at birth.

questions.question: A 35 y/o female with a cosmetically concerning mole on her right cheek. It is a raised, skin-colored papule, approximately 4 mm in diameter. The patient reports no change in size, shape, or color of the mole, and it has been present for several years. What would be the most appropriate treatment approach for this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Laser treatment Explanation: Melanocytic nevi: Also called moles. They are proliferating nevus cells derived from the neural crest. Acquired melanocytic nevi are nests of proliferating nevus cells and are classified into three types: Junctional nevi : Present at the dermo-epidermal junction which are small and dark brown. Compound nevi : Present at the dermo-epidermal junction and the dermis as these are slightly raised and lighter in color than junctional nevi. Intradermal nevi : Present in the dermis are raised papules that are either skin-colored or red. Treatment is usually done for cosmetic reasons, if indicative of malignancy, treatment options include electrocautery, laser treatment, and surgical excision. Congenital melanocytic nevi are present at birth. Giant congenital melanocytic nevi (also called bathing trunk/garment nevi) may have malignant potential. Halo nevi presents as a nevus with a halo around it which is caused by the autoimmune destruction of melanocytes surrounding the mole. Option A: Topical corticosteroids are primarily used to reduce inflammation and are not indicated in the treatment of melanocytic nevi. Option B: Oral antibiotics are used for bacterial infections and are not relevant to the treatment of intradermal nevi Option D: While intradermal nevi are benign, watchful waiting is not the most appropriate approach in this case. Reference: https://www.uptodate.com/contents/benign-pigmented-skin-lesions-other-than-melanocytic-nevi-moles?s earch=nevus%20of%20ito&sectionRank=1&usage_type=default&anchor=H18&source=machineLearning&select edTitle=1%7E10&display_rank=1#H18

questions.question: A 45-year-old fair-skinned woman presents with multiple tan to dark brown macules on her face and the dorsal aspect of her hands. These macules are 3 to 20 mm in size and have appeared after chronic sun exposure. Which of the following therapeutic options is not indicated for the treatment of these lesions?
questions.explanation: brown macules on her face and the dorsal aspect of her hands. These macules are 3 to 20 mm in size and have appeared after chronic sun exposure which can be diagnosed as solar lentigines Solar lentigines are benign pigmented skin lesions that occur in response to excessive or chronic sun exposure. Treatment for solar lentigines is generally unnecessary unless for cosmetic purposes. Therapeutic options include lightening agents, retinoic acid, trichloroacetic acid, cryotherapy, and laser therapy. However, antibiotic therapy is not indicated for the treatment of solar lentigines. Cryotherapy involves using extreme cold to destroy abnormal tissues such as solar lentigines. It works by freezing the affected area, leading to cellular destruction and subsequent sloughing off of the lesion. Trichloroacetic acid (TCA) is used for chemical peels and treating conditions like solar lentigines. It induces controlled skin injury, leading to exfoliation and skin regeneration. TCA effectively removes superficial skin layers, including pigmented lesions.

questions.question: Which of the following statements accurately describes the role of melanosomes in determining skin pigmentation?

options.A: An increased number of melanocytes causes darker skin pigmentation.
options.B: Larger melanosomes are found in individuals with lighter skin tones.
options.C: The degradation rate of melanosomes is same across different skin types.
options.D: The arrangement of melanosomes influences skin pigmentation.

questions.explanation: keratinocytes, which in turn affects skin pigmentation. Larger melanosomes, observed in darker skin tones, are typically dispersed individually. Melanin Types and Production: Two main types: Eumelanin : Brownish-black, responsible for darker skin tones. Pheomelanin : Orangish-red, found in lighter skin tones. Synthesis process (Melanogenesis): Melanosomes : Melanin is stored within specialized organelles called melanosomes, which are produced by melanocytes. Size and Distribution: Darker skin: Larger melanosomes (Option A) Lighter skin: Smaller melanosomes (Option B) Degradation: (Option C) Varies between skin types. Lighter skin: Melanosome complexes show degradative changes due to lysosomal enzymes. Darker skin: Larger melanosomes can remain intact up to the stratum corneum. Melanin and Skin Color: Key factors: Type of melanin, Melanosome size, Melanosome distribution (dispersed vs. aggregated), Skin color is NOT solely determined by the number of melanocytes. Regulation of Pigmentation : UV radiation Hormones: Estrogens - increase pigmentation; Melanocortins - melanin production. Reference: Rook’s Textbook of Dermatology 9th edition page no 88.1 -88.8
